questions.text: A G2P1 came to the labour room for safe confinement on EDD. The labour was progressing. The consultant told the intern who was assisting the labour the WHO guidelines in the second stage of labour. One of them was “manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of the head” as told above, all are the boundaries of the perineum except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sacrospinous ligaments The sacrospinous ligament does not form an anatomical boundary of the perineum.

Highyeild:

The perineum is a diamond-shaped region that overlies the pelvic outlet. Boundaries of perineum .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A . Anteriorly: Pubic symphysis and its arcuate ligament Option B . Posterolaterally: Sacrotuberous ligaments Option D . Posteriorly : Coccyx - Anterolaterally : Ischiopubic rami and the ischial tuberosities

questions.text: According to Caldwell-Moloy classification, the given image is which type of pelvis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gynecoid The Caldwell–Moloy anatomical classification of the pelvis is based on shape , and its concepts aid an understanding of labour mechanisms. Specifically, the greatest transverse diameter of the inlet and its division into anterior and posterior segments are used to classify the pelvis as gynaecoid, anthropoid, android, or platypelloid. The posterior segment determines the type of pelvis, whereas the anterior segment determines the tendency.

Solution:

Pelvic assessment Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) is the disparity in the relation between the head of the fetus and the pelvis. Both the fetus and pelvis are normal, but disproportionate. The best predictor of CPD is the trial of labour . A trial of labour is done only for mild CPD at the level of the pelvic inlet . If CPD is expected at the level of cavity or outlet – a trial of labour is not attempted. Clinically: By per abdomen examination/bimanual examination (Muller- munrokerr method). The bimanual method is superior to the abdominal method as pelvic assessment can be done simultaneously. Other options are also used to assess but pelvic assessment is the best method.

Extraedge:

Limitations of clinical assessment: It can assess the disproportion of the brim and not of the mid pelvis or outlet. The fetal head can be used as a pelvimeter to elicit only the contraction in the anteroposterior plane of the inlet. (If contraction affects the transverse diameter of the inlet, it is of less use).

questions.text: Information obtained by lateral plate X-ray pelvimetry is all true except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bispinous diameter Bispinous diameter can be measured by the anteroposterior view and not by the lateral view of X-ray pelvimetry.

Highyeild:

X-ray pelvimetry is of limited value in the diagnosis of pelvic contraction or cephalopelvic disproportion. Apart from pelvic capacity, there are several other factors involved in successful vaginal delivery. These are the fetal size, presentation, position and force of uterine contractions. X-ray pelvimetry cannot assess the other factors. It cannot reliably predict the likelihood of vaginal delivery neither in breech presentation nor in cases with previous cesarean section. X-ray pelvimetry is useful in cases with a fractured pelvis and for the important diameters which are inaccessible to clinical examination.

Extraedge:

Hazards of X-ray pelvimetry include radiation exposure to the mother and the fetus. With conventional X-ray pelvimetry radiation exposure to the gonads is about 885 millirad . So it is restricted to selected cases only.

questions.text: The following are the features of “dystocia dystrophia syndrome” except:

options.label: A
options.text: The patient is stockily built with short thighs

questions.explanation:
Solution:

They have normal fertility Dystocia dystrophia syndrome. It is characterized by the following features: They are usually subfertile, having dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhoea or irregular periods. There is an increased incidence of preeclampsia and a tendency for postmaturity during pregnancy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . The patient is stockily built with a bull neck, broad shoulders and short thighs. She is obese with a male distribution of hairs. Option: C. Pelvis is of the Android type. Occipitoposterior position is common. Option: D . During labour, inertia is common and there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia leading to either the increased incidence of difficult instrumental delivery or cesarean section. There are increased chances of lactation failure during purpureum.
